docs.snippet: Reggie Johnson isn't going to take Will Taylor lightly when the two meet in Miami tomorrow night in a light heavyweight championship bout.     Johnson (38-5-1) won his International Boxing Federation lightweight title from William Guthrie a year a...
docs.lead_paragraph: Reggie Johnson isn't going to take Will Taylor lightly when the two meet in Miami tomorrow night in a light heavyweight championship bout. Johnson (38-5-1) won his International Boxing Federation lightweight title from William Guthrie a year ago with a one-punch knockout. Johnson, who had been the World Boxing Association middleweight champion, moved up two weight classes to take on Guthrie.
docs.abstract: Reggie Johnson to meet Will Taylor in light heavyweight championship bout in Miami on Feb 27 (S)

headline.main: Johnson Moving Up For Bout With Taylor

docs.snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-10    Ethnic Albanians Agree To Kosovo Peace Pact  The ethnic Albanian delegation at the Kosovo talks agreed in principle to a peace settlement, turning at the last minute what appeared to be an almost certain collapse for the C...
docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Ethnic Albanians Agree To Kosovo Peace Pact The ethnic Albanian delegation at the Kosovo talks agreed in principle to a peace settlement, turning at the last minute what appeared to be an almost certain collapse for the Clinton Administration's peace effort into a limited success. American officials acknowledged that the result was far from what they needed to pressure Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav President. A1 Serbian army and police forces traded missile fire with guerrillas in a northern Kosovo village for the second day in a row, as the residents cowered in their houses. A10

docs.snippet: NEWS    Polar Bearers    The rock musician Stevie Wonder and the Greek-born composer Yannis Xenakis have been named winners of the Swedish Academy of Music's 1999 Polar Music Prizes. Established by the Swedish record company owner Stikkan Anderson...
docs.lead_paragraph: NEWS Polar Bearers The rock musician Stevie Wonder and the Greek-born composer Yannis Xenakis have been named winners of the Swedish Academy of Music's 1999 Polar Music Prizes. Established by the Swedish record company owner Stikkan Anderson in 1992, the annual awards to a popular and a so-called serious musician carry a prize of $127,000 each, to be presented in ceremonies in Stockholm on May 31. The jury described Mr. Wonder, 49, as one of the great personalities on the rock music scene and acclaimed Mr. Xenakis, 77, for his ''vitalizing'' and ''creative methods.''
docs.abstract: Musician Stevie Wonder and Greek-born composer Yannis Xenakis are named winners of Swedish Academy of Music's 1999 Polar Music Prizes; awards, worth $127,000 each, are to be presented in ceremonies in Stockholm on May 31; photo of Wonder; RCA Victor releases album Side Man: Jazz Classics From the Broadway Hit; fifth annual US Comedy Arts Festival to be held in Aspen, Colo, March 3 to 7; attending will be Neil Simon, James L Brooks and Ben Stiller, among others; photo of Simon; Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences pays tribute to Robert Osborne, official biographer of Academy Awards, with celebration at Museum of Modern Art of his new book, 70 Years of the Oscar: The Official History of the Academy Awards; Norwegian authorities recapture Paal Enger, who was serving six-year sentence for stealing a national treasure, Edvard Munch's painting The Scream, from National Gallery in Oslo in 1994; Enger escaped from prison on Feb 10 (M)

docs.snippet: Amid the usual gloomy talk about fickle television watchers who incessantly flip to cable channels, February so far has brought at least some good cheer to each of the six broadcast networks.    ABC's Stephen King mini-series, ''Storm of the Centu...
docs.lead_paragraph: Amid the usual gloomy talk about fickle television watchers who incessantly flip to cable channels, February so far has brought at least some good cheer to each of the six broadcast networks. ABC's Stephen King mini-series, ''Storm of the Century,'' stood up to the powerful competition from NBC better than expected on Thursday, even up against the much advertised episode of NBC's ''E.R.'' in which George Clooney made his final appearance as Dr. Ross. Although the 12.0 household rating for ''Storm'' (each rating points equals 994,000 homes) was modest, it raised ABC to a 10.6 average household rating for the night, its best Thursday rating in nearly five years.
docs.abstract: February brings at least some good ratings news to each of six broadcast networks; CBS's 60 Minutes, responding to public debate over broadcast last Nov 30 of videotape of Thomas Youk's death from fatal doses of drug administered by Dr Jack Kevorkian, will present another side of story this Sunday: five people who have Lou Gehrig's disease, or amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, as Youk did, but who have chosen to live and cope with it (M)

docs.snippet: Perhaps the most striking thing about the decision to give Elia Kazan an honorary Academy Award at this year's ceremony is the fact that it was made unanimously. The 39-member board of the Motion Picture Academy of Arts and Sciences approved the c...
docs.lead_paragraph: Perhaps the most striking thing about the decision to give Elia Kazan an honorary Academy Award at this year's ceremony is the fact that it was made unanimously. The 39-member board of the Motion Picture Academy of Arts and Sciences approved the choice of Mr. Kazan ''with enthusiasm,'' according to one board member, and without debate. If so, it is the first time Mr. Kazan has failed to provoke debate since early 1952, when he twice appeared before the House Un-American Activities Committee, informed against eight friends and took out an ad in The Times to explain, with rather incomplete logic, the reasons for his actions. In response to the news of Mr. Kazan's upcoming Oscar, a subdued protest -- the omission of applause -- has been organized by former blacklisted writers and their families and friends. The protest is certainly merited, but so is the award, for Mr. Kazan's truly distinguished work as the director of films like ''A Streetcar Named Desire'' and ''On the Waterfront.''
docs.abstract: Editorial holds Elia Kazan merits both honorary Academy Award and planned subdued protest organized by former blacklisted writers and their families and friends

docs.snippet: Linda Tripp and Christopher Hitchens may be the most famous canaries of the Starr war, but Elia Kazan was the most famous canary of the cold war.    High in the Hollywood Hills, Bernard Gordon, a writer who was blacklisted, is working to make sure...
docs.lead_paragraph: Linda Tripp and Christopher Hitchens may be the most famous canaries of the Starr war, but Elia Kazan was the most famous canary of the cold war. High in the Hollywood Hills, Bernard Gordon, a writer who was blacklisted, is working to make sure that on Oscar night Mr. Kazan does not escape his past. Mr. Gordon, now 79, is naming names. The name he gives the dazzling director -- who will be awarded an honorary Oscar by the Motion Picture Academy -- is Rat Fink.
docs.abstract: Maureen Dowd column compares behavior of Elia Kazan, who named names before House Committee on Un-American Activities in 1950's, with the acts of 'treachery' that framed the Clinton impeachment scandal: Linda Tripp's betrayal of Monica S Lewinsky and Christopher Hitchens's of Sidney Blumenthal; asserts that the smallness of the times we live in is revealed even in our betrayals (M)

docs.snippet: Slowly and quietly, plans are being made for a series of protests over the decision by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to present an honorary Oscar to the 89-year-old director Elia Kazan.    Mr. Kazan was perhaps the most formidabl...
docs.lead_paragraph: Slowly and quietly, plans are being made for a series of protests over the decision by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to present an honorary Oscar to the 89-year-old director Elia Kazan. Mr. Kazan was perhaps the most formidable filmmaker of the 1950's and 60's, with such movies as ''On the Waterfront,'' ''A Streetcar Named Desire,'' ''A Face in the Crowd'' and ''East of Eden.'' But he has not been forgiven by some writers, actors and others for appearing before the House Committee on Un-American Activities on April 10, 1952, during the height of the McCarthy era. He informed on eight old friends from the Group Theater who, along with him, had once belonged to the Communist Party.
docs.abstract: Plans are being made for series of protests over decision by Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to present honorary Oscar to 89-year-old director Elia Kazan; Kazan, perhaps most formidable filmmaker of 1950's and 60's, has not been forgiven by some writers, actors and others for appearing before House Committee on Un-American Activities on April 10, 1952, during height of McCarthy era; he informed on eight old friends from Group Theater who, along with him, had once belonged to Communist Party; photo (M)

headline.main: Kazan Honor Stirs Protest By Blacklist Survivors

docs.snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-12    White House Spurns China By Rejecting Satellite Deal  The Clinton Administration, swayed by criticisms that commercial satellite deals with China could threaten national security, decided to reject the sale of a $450 milli...
docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 White House Spurns China By Rejecting Satellite Deal The Clinton Administration, swayed by criticisms that commercial satellite deals with China could threaten national security, decided to reject the sale of a $450 million satellite to a consortium with close ties to the Chinese Government, senior Administration officials said. The move runs counter to a policy of promoting commercial satellite deals with China and casts doubt on the future of other high-technology sales to the Chinese. A1

docs.snippet: Some voices are cherishable because they so completely define a particular vocal category. But others excite us because they seem to transcend all the categories, as does the Finnish soprano Karita Mattila, who made her Carnegie Hall recital debut...
docs.lead_paragraph: Some voices are cherishable because they so completely define a particular vocal category. But others excite us because they seem to transcend all the categories, as does the Finnish soprano Karita Mattila, who made her Carnegie Hall recital debut on Friday night with the elegant pianist Ilmo Ranta, her frequent collaborator. Ms. Mattila began her career as a bright-toned lyric soprano. Over the years her voice, while retaining its lyric cast, has grown naturally in power and resonance. At 38, she is now in her thrilling prime. As Wagner's Elsa and Verdi's Amelia at the Metropolitan Opera this season, she sang with an unforced, focused radiance that many a dramatic soprano would covet yet with no sacrifice of lyric colors.
docs.abstract: Anthony Tommasini reviews soprano Karita Mattila's Carnegie Hall recital debut; photo (M)

headline.main: A Finnish Diva to Dream About

docs.snippet: Pernell Whitaker knew he would have to deploy more offense than usual to defeat Felix Trinidad Jr., the International Boxing Federation welterweight champion, at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night. Whitaker also knew that that strategy meant ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Pernell Whitaker knew he would have to deploy more offense than usual to defeat Felix Trinidad Jr., the International Boxing Federation welterweight champion, at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night. Whitaker also knew that that strategy meant a greater risk of getting hit -- something that Whitaker had arduously avoided during his 14-year career. Whitaker took the plunge, and he took a beating, the worst of his long, illustrious career. Trinidad (34-0) pounded out a 12-round unanimous decision to keep his title and set up an even bigger welterweight showdown against Oscar De La Hoya, the World Boxing Council champion.
docs.abstract: Article discusses Felix Trinidad Jr's successful defense of his International Boxing Federation welterweight championship over Pernell Whitaker; photo (M)

headline.main: Trinidad Pounds Whitaker; Awaits Shot at De La Hoya
